did.head: Overview
did.abstract: The collection conists chiefly of correspondence, diaries, notebooks, scrapbooks, business and estate records, writings, lectures, and gardening papers. Correspondents include family members such as Lionel Edward Sackville-West, Victoria Sackville, Harold Nicolson, and Nigel Nicolson, and friends and lovers including Rosamund Grosvenor, Hilda Matheson, Gwen St. Aubyn, and Christopher St. John. Writings include typescripts and manuscripts for works including the novels The Edwardians and All Passion Spent. Gardening papers include horticultural catalogs, files on the National Trust's garden committee, and research materials. The collection documents Vita Sackville-West's family life, love affairs with women including Christopher St. John and Gwen St. Aubyn, her literary life and circle, including both Sackville-West's work and that of friends including Virginia Woolf, and the management of the Sissinghurst Castle estate and gardens.

processinfo.head: Processing Notes
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Vita Sackville-West
bioghist.p: Vita (Victoria) Sackville-West (1892-1962), was an English author, poet and gardener. She was the daughter of Lionel Sackville-West, 3rd Baron Sackville, and Victoria Sackville-West. She and her husband Sir Harold Nicolson created the gardens at their Sissinghurst Castle estate.

scopecontent.head: Description of the Papers
scopecontent.p:
The collection consists chiefly of correspondence, diaries, notebooks, scrapbooks, business and estate records, writings, lectures, and gardening papers. Correspondents include family members such as Lionel Edward Sackville-West, Victoria Sackville, Harold Nicolson, and Nigel Nicolson, and friends and lovers including Rosamund Grosvenor, Hilda Matheson, Gwen St. Aubyn, and Christopher St. John. Writings include typescripts and manuscripts for works including the novels
The Edwardians and
All Passion Spent . Gardening papers include horticultural catalogs, files on the National Trust's garden committee, and research materials. The collection documents Vita Sackville-West's family life, love affairs with women including Christopher St. John and Gwen St. Aubyn, her literary life and circle, including both Sackville-West's work and that of friends including Virginia Woolf, and the management of the Sissinghurst Castle estate and gardens.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Correspondence, 1900s-1990s. II. Personal Papers, 1900s-1960s. III. Writings and Lectures, 1920s-1990s. IV. Gardening Papers, 1930s-1960s.

scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence sent from home and abroad to Rosamund Grosvenor, with copies of letters written on her honeymoon and from Constantinople, Hilda Matheson, Lady Sackville (Mama), and others. Also contains some photographs and correspondence from others including Nigel Nicolson.
Includes correspondence from Pat Dansey, Sybil Colefax, Cyril Connolly, Lady Sackville, Ruth Draper, Rosamund Grosvenor and others

Includes correspondence from Harold Nicolson, Lady Powerscourt, Lady Sackville, Gwen St. Aubyn, Christopher St. John, Lord Sackville, and others. Also includes third-party correspondence to Lady Sackville from Scott Geoffrey, from Lord Sackville to Lady Sackville, and others.

Includes correspondence from Margaret Voyt, Hilda Matheson, and Laura James, family correspondence between Vita Sackville-West and her mother and father, and other correspondence. Also includes photographs of Hilda Matheson and excerpts from correspondence with Margaret Howard.

Includes travel diaries, daybooks, and gardening notebooks. Also contains news clippings and Christopher St. John's "horrifying document," a manuscript notebook detailing the end of her affair with Sackville-West in 1933.
Includes travel diaries, daybooks, and gardening notebooks. Also contains at least one datebook kept by Lady Sackville.
Financial statements and correspondence documenting the managment of the Sissinghurst Castle estate, personal property, and Lady Sackville's death.
Includes news clippings covering Vita Sackville-West's publications and one scrapbook with clippings about Virginia Woolf.
